statement.para: Here are some examples of n-tuples:

li.para: (5) is a 1-tuple. Its one and only coordinate is the number 5. (-3) is another 1-tuple, and an arbitrary 1-tuple is of the form (s), with s a number in the system of real numbers \RNr.

(2,3) is a 2-tuple, or a pair of numbers. The first coordinate of this 2-tuple is 2. The second coordinate is 3. Another 2-tuple is (-1,6). In this case the first coordinate of this 2-tuple is -1, the second coordinate is 6.
An arbitrary 2-tuple, or pair of numbers, is of the form (s,t) with s and t numbers. In this case the first coordinate is s, while the second coordinate is t.

(\tfrac{3}{2},0,-1) is a 3-tuple, or a triple of numbers. Its first coordinate is \tfrac{3}{2}. Its second coordinate is 0. Its third coordinate is -1. Another 3-tuple is (-16,3,4). In this case the first coordinate is -16, the second coordinate is 3, the third coordinate is 4.
An arbitrary 3-tuple, or triple of numbers, is of the form (x,y,z) with x, y, and z numbers. In this case the first coordinate is x, the second coordinate is y, and the third coordinate is z.
(4,1,0,3) is a 4-tuple. Its first coordinate is 4. Its second coordinate is 1. Its third coordinate is 0. Its fourth coordinate is 3; etc.
